entry.title: Building a Generative AI-powered Inventory Assistant with SAP CAP, RAG, and Vector Database
entry.content:
Introduction

In modern enterprises, inventory management is no longer just about tracking numbers — it's about accessing the right information at the right time and enabling fast, data-driven decisions. Today, Generative AI offers a powerful opportunity to make these processes smarter, faster, and more intuitive.

In this project, I transformed a stock management application built with SAP CAP (Node.js) on SAP BTP into an intelligent decision assistant by integrating Generative AI, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) , and a vector database .

The application interprets natural language queries, finds relevant products using embedding-based similarity search , retrieves real records from the database, and — thanks to the grounding approach — generates responses strictly based on actual data. This prevents hallucinations and ensures a trusted enterprise AI experience.

A key learning resource for this development was the SAP Learning Journey
“Solving Business Problems using SAP's Generative AI Hub”
which helped me explore and apply Generative AI concepts in real SAP BTP scenarios.

In this blog, I will walk through the architecture, implementation details, and the technical components behind this solution.

 

STEP 1:

We set up the Basic CAP file structure  with "cds init" in the terminal 

 

  • Creates package.json and config files

  • Prepares db, srv, app folders

And then .envwe define our Gemini API key in the file in the project root directory.

 

Then we create the "serice.cds and service.js" files under the "SRV" folder.

and we define "service.cds" as follows:

namespace ai;

using data from '../db/products';


type ChatTurn {
  role   : String;  
  content: String;
}

type ChatResponse {
  content : String;
}


service ProductService @(path:'/products') {
  entity Products as projection on data.Products;

}

service AIService @(path:'/ai') {
  : { method: 'POST', path: 'chat' }
  action chat(message: String, history: many ChatTurn) returns ChatResponse;

 
}

  • ChatTurn: Represents each line of conversation (role: user/assistant, content: message)

  • ChatResponse: Response format returned from chat (an object containing only content)

These structures are used for AI chat API .

 

And right below, we define a "product" service that exposes product data to the outside.

This section 

  • /productsvia endpoint

  • data.Productsshows his painting to the outside world

Just below this, we define the AI ​​service .
This service is the structure that responds to user requests sent in natural language.

We created an action inside the service chatcalled . In the CAP world, action is used to execute special business logic outside of classic CRUD operations (CREATE/READ/UPDATE/DELETE).

This chataction:

  • message: text written by the user,

  • history: previous conversation history

takes and

  • ChatResponse: that is, the answer generated by artificial intelligence

returns.

In short, this action is the bridge between the UI side and the LLM. When
the user POST /ai/chatsubmits the request, the CAP service.jsruns the relevant code within it; it reads the product data, applies vector lookup and grounding, and then generates a response from the LLM.

 

After completing the service definition, we need to create the data model that will store the product data the application will use. This structure dbis defined in the CAP layer. Here, I defined an entity for the products and uploaded the initial data to the system via a CSV file.

In the data layer of the application, I defined three basic entities for inventory management and artificial intelligence operations:

namespace data;

entity Products {
  ID        : UUID @key;
  sku       : String(60) ;
  name      : String(200);
  price     : Decimal(15,2);
  currency  : String(3) default 'TRY';
  stock     : Integer default 0;
  category  : String(80);
  brand     : String(80);
  color     : String(40);
  barcode   : String(32);
  weight    : Decimal(10,3); 
  unit      : String(10) default 'adet';
  description: String(1000);
  createdAt : Timestamp default current_timestamp;
  updatedAt : Timestamp;
}

entity Embeddings {
  ID         : UUID @key;
  product    : Association to Products;
  chunkIndex : Integer;          
  text       : String(5000);    
  embedding  : LargeString;       
  model      : String(100);      
  dim        : Integer;       
  createdAt  : Timestamp default current_timestamp;
}

entity ProductVectors {
  sku       : String(60) @key;
  embedding : LargeString;
}

Products— Product Main Table

This table stores basic product information in the system.
Fields contain actual commercial parameters such as product name, price, and stock quantity.

Embeddings— Text Embedding Archive

This table is designed to store embeddings of product descriptions.
Embedding a product can be done by splitting it into multiple pieces of text, rather than as a single line.

ProductVectors— Fast Vector Lookup Table

This table holds a simplified version of the product SKU and embeddings.

For the project, I created a product dataset for testing purposes.
This CSV file contains basic product information used in the application's inventory query, embedding generation, and vector search processes.

We're using the CAP command to create the product and vector tables in the project deploy.
The following command takes the CDS data model and applies it to SQLite as a live database:

cds deploy --to sqlite:sqlite.db

 

 

 
 

Embedding Process and Data Preparation

The tables above form the data infrastructure of the application.
In the next step, the product text must be embedded and transferred to the vector index table.

This process takes place in two stages:

1 Converting product descriptions to embeddings 2 Loading
embeddings into the table for quick searchProductVectors

For this purpose, I added two helper scripts to the project:

 
/tools
 ├─ embed.js          
 └─ init-vectors.js
 
These scripts are run once before the application runs and prepare the RAG infrastructure.

 

What is Embedding? 

Embedding is the process of converting text into a vector of numbers. In other words, it's a way of mathematically representing
text, words, or product descriptions .

try {
  require("dotenv").config();
} catch (e) {}
const cds = require("@sap/cds");
const { GoogleGenerativeAI } = require("@google/generative-ai");

async function embed(text) {
  const KEY = process.env.GEMINI_API_KEY;
  const genAI = new GoogleGenerativeAI(KEY);
  const model = genAI.getGenerativeModel({ model: "text-embedding-004" });
  const res = await model.embedContent(text);
  return res?.embedding?.values || [];
}

(async () => {
  const db = await cds.connect.to("db");
  const products = await db.run(`SELECT sku, name FROM data_Products`);
  for (const p of products) {
    const text = `${p.sku} ${p.name}`;
    const vec = await embed(text);
    await db.run(
      `INSERT OR REPLACE INTO data_ProductVectors (sku, embedding) VALUES (?, ?)`,
      [p.sku, JSON.stringify(vec)]
    );
    console.log("✓ embedded:", p.sku);
  }
  console.log(" Bitti");
  process.exit(0);
})();
// Note: To run this file, use the following in the terminal:
//    node tools/embed.js

To run the embedding script, use the following command in the terminal:

node tools/embed.js

When this command is run, product descriptions are converted to embeddings via the Gemini API and saved in the Embeddings table. This step is only performed when data is loaded or the product list changes.

 

Passing Embeddings to Vector Lookup Table (init-vectors.js):

Once the embeddings are created, we need to load this data into the SQLite vector table for fast vector search.

At this stage, I run the init-vectors.js script.

This script: Reads the Embeddings table Converts vectors to Float32 format.

Writes to the ProductVectors table. This makes it possible to search for cosine similarity / L2 distance on SQLite.

node tools/init-vectors.js

The embeddings and vector table are ready.
At this point, let's add the plugin to the project to enable vector similarity calculation in SQLite sqlite-vec:

sqlite-extensions/
 └─ vec0.dll

This plugin adds the following functionality to SQLite:

  • vec_distance_cos() — Cosine similarity

  • vec_distance_l2() — L2 (Euclidean) distance

  • vec_version()— Version control

You can download it from the link below.

https://github.com/asg017/sqlite-vec/releases 

Here's how I install the plugin in Node.js:

const dll = path.resolve(__dirname, "..", "sqlite-extensions", "vec0.dll");
if (fs.existsSync(dll)) db.loadExtension(dll);
In this way the CAP service can work as an embedded vector database .

Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) Phase

To this point, we've prepared the application's data infrastructure, loaded the products into the system, converted them to embedding (numeric vector) format, and established a structure capable of vector searching on SQLite. Now, we're moving on to the real intelligence: the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) process.

The primary goal of the RAG approach is to prevent AI from relying solely on the model it was trained on and to enable it to produce more accurate, reliable, and contextual results by accessing real data. In this project, we implemented this as follows:

When a user types a stock-related query in natural language, the system first embeds the query and identifies the most relevant SKUs by performing a vector similarity search on SQLite-Vec. The actual records for these products are then retrieved from the SAP CAP database and provided as grounding for the Gemini model. This ensures that the AI ​​generates its response based solely on existing product data, eliminating any hallucinations.

R — Retrieval (Finding information):

The query from the user ( ) queryis converted into an embedding and this embedding finds similar products using SQLite-Vec:

const qvec = await embed(query);
if (!qvec.length)
  return { error: "Embedding üretilemedi (Gemini).", products: [] };


const buf = toFloat32Buffer(qvec);
rows = db
  .prepare(`
    SELECT sku, vec_distance_cos(embedding, ?) AS dist
    FROM vec_product_vectors
    ORDER BY dist ASC
    LIMIT 5
  `)
  .all(buf);

In this phase, the system translates the user's natural language query into a numerical vector and returns the closest product placements based on vector similarity (cosine distance). In other words, this is where the "finding related information"
step occurs.

A — Augmentation (Adding contextual data)

Actual product records are pulled from the CAP database using the found SKUs :

const skus = rows.map((r) => r.sku);
const products = await cds.run`
  SELECT *
  FROM data.Products
  WHERE sku in ${skus}
`;

At this point:

  • Actual commercial data (product name, price, stock, category, etc.) are taken from the system.

  • The model is now prepared to produce answers with only this data.

In other words , the Retrieval result is strengthened with real information by being “Augmented” .

Generation (Answer generation)

The model generates an answer based solely on the above data with the grounding rule:

const prompt = `Kullanıcı: "${query}"

Ürün verileri (sadece bunlara dayan):
${lines}

Kurallar:
- Sadece yukarıdaki verilere dayan, uydurma bilgi verme.
- Kısa ve net Türkçe cevap ver.
- Eğer kullanıcı spesifik SKU/ürün sormamışsa, en yakın 1-3 uygun ürünü özetle.
`;

const answer = await callGemini(prompt);
return { content: answer };

Here:

  • The model is fed only with real data .

  • Grounding is provided with the “do not provide fabricated information” rule .

  • As a result, the model generates a reliable and context-based response.

RESULT:

With this project, we transformed a traditional inventory management application running on SAP CAP into an intelligent decision support system based on real data. Thanks to embedding, vector search, grounding, and Gemini integration, users can now search for products using natural language, and the model generates reliable and consistent answers based solely on existing corporate data. This approach provides a concrete example of how to improve processes with AI in businesses.

GİTHUB: https://github.com/furkanaksy838/Stock-asistan.git

entry.title: High CPU Load(100%) every minute in ERP environment with 130 Users
entry.content:
Hello specialists! 

We have a problem with a customers sql anywhere 17 database. 

Since the beginning of the year we have the case that our ERP Customer has Problems with CPU Peaks (100%). The peaks will come about every 60 seconds and last four about 10 - 20 seconds. 

What we have done already: 

- Unload and reload the databases (moren than 4 times). 

- CREATE STATISTICS all tables every night.

- Deactivating Triggers 

- Disabling new Software Features we brought in through the year. 

 

Nothing helped. Sometimes it runs smooth for an amount of days (in the beginning sometimes for weeks). Sometimes it comes back the next work day. 

Any help how to get rid of the problem would be nice ! 

Hope someone can help us. 

Greetz

Nik

entry.title: SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration – Cloud based ERP Synchronization of Technical Objects
entry.content:
SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration (BNAC) is a cloud-based Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution hosted on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). It enables seamless collaboration among all stakeholders involved in the lifecycle of physical assets—such as component suppliers, manufacturers, operators, and service providers.
At the core of BNAC lies a centralized repository that maintains digital twins (digital replicas) of physical assets. Acting as a kind of "social network for assets," BNAC facilitates real-time sharing of asset-related data, including technical specifications, documentation, and maintenance activities.
By supporting this networked collaboration model, BNAC enhances transparency, operational reliability, and asset performance, while also helping organizations reduce maintenance costs and improve safety. It integrates tightly with SAP S/4HANA, SAP Intelligent Asset Management, and SAP Fieldglass, offering a unified platform for asset data governance and cross-organizational maintenance coordination.
More information about SAP BNAC can be found here.

In today’s interconnected asset management landscape, synchronization between cloud applications and backend ERP systems is critical. BNAC serves as a key platform for managing technical objects like Equipment and Functional Locations. However, until recently, synchronization from BNAC to ERP (S/4 HANA or ECC) could only occur during the object creation process. If ERP details were not entered at that time, there was no option to sync the object afterward, often resulting in data silos and manual workarounds.
To enhance the integration process, SAP has introduced a cloud-based ERP synchronization control for technical objects (Equipment and Functional Location) that allows users to trigger synchronization both during and after object creation. This enhancement provides greater flexibility, reduces errors, and supports a more dynamic and user-driven approach to maintaining synchronized data across systems.

In this blog post, we’ll:

  • Explore the challenges of the earlier synchronization process,
  • Walk through the new cloud-based ERP sync functionality, and
  • Highlight how it enhances data integrity, flexibility, and efficiency across the BNAC and ERP environments.

Note - This blog post focuses on technical objects that are owned by an organization — specifically, those created within its own BNAC tenant. It does not cover received technical objects, i.e., technical objects that have been shared with the organization by an external organization. While many of the functionalities and principles discussed here are largely applicable to received technical objects as well, their management and behavior may vary depending on ownership and sharing configurations. These aspects will be explored in greater detail in an upcoming blog post dedicated to the handling of received/shared technical objects.

The Challenge with Existing Synchronization Process

Before the introduction of cloud-based control for ERP synchronization in SAP BNAC, the synchronization process was tightly coupled with the initial creation of technical objects. When creating an equipment or functional location in BNAC, users were required to enter ERP system details if they intended for the object to be replicated in the ERP backend system.

This presented several challenges:

  • No Post-Creation Sync Option: If ERP details were not provided during object creation, there was no option to trigger synchronization at a later stage. The object would remain in BNAC only, with no way to push it to ERP afterward.
  • Risk of Incomplete or Incorrect Data: Users often create objects incrementally or collaboratively. The requirement to include ERP details upfront increases the risk of entering incomplete or placeholder data just to initiate sync, leading to errors downstream.
  • Limited Flexibility for Business Processes: In many real-world scenarios, ERP integration decisions or assignments are finalized after the object is created. The lack of post-creation sync capability forced users to recreate objects or manage duplicate data. 

New Cloud-Based Control for ERP Synchronization

SAP BNAC now offers a powerful enhancement that significantly improves the process of synchronizing technical objects (Equipment and Functional Locations) with SAP ERP.

This enhanced capability empowers users to:

  • Avoid common synchronization bottlenecks
  • Maintain accurate and consistent asset data
  • Seamlessly align technical objects from BNAC to ERP systems — all within a flexible cloud environment

This enables retrospective ERP synchronization, eliminating the need to recreate technical objects when the ERP system details are not provided during object creation, and supporting better lifecycle management of these technical objects.

With this mechanism, users now have greater flexibility and full control over when and how technical objects are synchronized with ERP:

  • During Object Creation: Users can continue to provide ERP system details while creating the object in BNAC. If all required fields are correctly filled, synchronization is triggered automatically as the existing synchronization process.
  • Post-Creation Synchronization: Objects created without ERP details are no longer prevented from synchronization. Users can now edit existing objects in BNAC to add the required ERP system information and mandatory fields. Once these details are provided, synchronization to the connected ERP system can be manually triggered, allowing greater flexibility and control over the data integration process.

To support the cloud-based ERP synchronization process, three new fields have been introduced in both the Object Creation dialog and the ERP Information section in BNAC UI:

  • ERP System – Mandatory (When selecting an ERP system for a Functional Location, the user will also be prompted to choose the corresponding Structure Indicator.)
  • Category – Mandatory
  • Proposed ERP ID – Optional
    The Proposed ERP ID field allows users to specify a custom ID for creating the object in SAP ERP. The behavior of this field varies slightly between Equipment and Functional Location.
    For Equipment: By default, equipment in SAP ERP is created using internally generated number. The Proposed ERP ID will be used only if external numbering is enabled in ERP for the selected equipment category. This is controlled through SPRO configuration for external number ranges and MAIF (SAP Mobile Add-on) configuration for equipment-related settings. If Proposed ERP ID is populated, this value will be used for equipment creation in ERP. Else, the Equipment ID from BNAC will be used for equipment creation.
    For Functional Location: If Proposed ERP ID is populated, this value will be used for Functional Location creation in ERP. Else, the ERP system will use the Functional Location ID for Functional Location creation in ERP.

For successful synchronization of a technical object from BNAC to ERP, the ERP System and Category fields are required.
Note - Always validate that the ERP fields are populated correctly before triggering sync to avoid errors or failed replication in ERP.

The triggering of ERP synchronization for an object can be controlled using the “SAP ERP Synchronization” toggle available in the object creation dialog for Equipment or Functional Location.

  • When the toggle is set to “Yes” and mandatory ERP fields are populated, the object will be synchronized with SAP ERP immediately upon creation.
  • When the toggle is set to “No”, the initial ERP sync with object creation will be skipped. Users can later initiate synchronization manually from BNAC after populating the mandatory ERP fields.   
    In this case, a Sync button will appear in the ERP Information section, allowing users to trigger ERP synchronization for the technical object at their convenience. When the Sync button is pressed, a pop-up will appear prompting the user to confirm whether they also want to synchronize the object’s associated hierarchy.
    If the checkbox is selected, ERP synchronization will be triggered for the main object and, also for all related technical objects beneath it in the BNAC hierarchy. Note: ERP synchronization for an object of the hierarchy will not be triggered if its category is missing, or if the external system is absent or does not match the main object.

Post-Creation Sync: Key Points to Remember

  • When the Sync button is pressed without the Hierarchy Sync option, it triggers the ERP synchronization process for the selected ERP system for the main technical object.
  • When the Sync button is pressed with the Hierarchy Sync option selected, it triggers the ERP synchronization process for the main technical object and all related objects beneath it in the hierarchy. The hierarchy will be created in ERP only if all objects within the structure are assigned to the same ERP system. Please note that an object will not be synchronized with ERP if it is linked to a different ERP system than the main technical object. Additionally, all objects must have the category field populated for successful synchronization.
  • Once the Sync button is pressed, it will be removed from the BNAC UI. Any subsequent updates to the BNAC object will be automatically synchronized with the ERP system.
  • If the initial synchronization fails in ERP and no external ID is generated for the technical object, no further events will be sent to ERP for that object and, ERP synchronization cannot be re-triggered. Please ensure all required ERP fields are correctly populated in BNAC before triggering the ERP synchronization.

Required SAP Notes and ERP Configurations for Cloud-Based Synchronization

To enable and use the new cloud-based ERP synchronization mechanism, the following prerequisites must be met in the ERP system:
SAP Note Implementation

  • Ensure that SAP Note 3500076 is implemented in your ERP system.
  • Complete all associated manual activities as outlined in the note to avoid integration issues.

MAIF (Mobile Add-on) Configuration
To support cloud-based synchronization, the following configurations must be maintained in the MAIF (Mobile Add-on) configuration panel - transaction /SYCLO/CONFIGPANEL:

  • Enable Cloud-Based ERP Synchronization by updating the relevant mobile data object settings under Mobile Data Object Configuration section.

    For Equipment - 

     For Functional Location - 

  • Add new SYNC event for equipment and functional location to listen for synchronization events triggered by the cloud-based ERP sync feature under oData Mobile Data Object Configuration section.

     

Benefits of the New Synchronization Capability

  • Increased flexibility – Sync technical objects when ready, not just during creation
  • Reduced rework – No need to delete and recreate objects due to missed ERP info
  • Improved data consistency – Aligned records across BNAC and ERP
  • Streamlined governance – Centralized control of asset lifecycle across systems
  • Better user experience – Simplified, intuitive sync management for end users

Best Practices & Recommendations

To get the most value from the new cloud-based synchronization capabilities in SAP BNAC, it’s important to follow a few best practices. These guidelines can help ensure successful integration with ERP systems and promote clean, reliable asset data.

  • Creation-Time Sync: Use this approach when ERP system details and required data fields are available at the time of object creation. This ensures the technical object is immediately created in ERP, avoiding delays and enabling early integration with maintenance or planning processes.
  • Post-Creation Sync: Ideal when ERP details are not yet finalized or when object creation is initiated by a user who may not have ERP access. Post-creation sync allows flexibility while still maintaining system integrity and ensures collaboration doesn't stall due to incomplete initial data.
  • Data Validation before Sync: It is essential to validate that all mandatory fields are completed according to business requirements before triggering ERP synchronization. Additionally, field values must comply with ERP data standards, such as value lists and classification types. Document links or attachments should be accessible and relevant, and hierarchies need to be logically structured with the same external system assigned to all components to ensure a successful hierarchy synchronization.

Summary

The introduction of cloud-based control of ERP synchronization in SAP BNAC marks a significant step forward in flexible, user-driven integration of technical objects across the asset lifecycle. By enabling synchronization both during and after object creation, SAP has empowered users to manage equipment and functional locations with greater autonomy and precision.
This enhancement promotes better data consistency, reduces rework, and supports smoother collaboration between asset stakeholders and ERP systems like SAP S/4HANA or ECC.

entry.title: Cannot find the Parallel line workspace in CBC
entry.content:
After requesting the parallel line tenant creation the parallel line workspace is not available in the CBC. Why I cannot see the already created parallel line workspace?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Cannot find the Parallel line workspace in CBC
entry.content:
Your user is probably not assigned to the Parallel Line Workspace (Settings -> Teams).

You can ask to the Program Manager to add yourself to the workspace. Or, you can assign SAP_CBC_CONSUMPTION_PROJECT_LEAD role to yourself and then you should be able to see the PL line.

You can refer to Standard Roles and Authorizations | SAP Help Portal 

It's important to add the role SAP_CBC_CONSUMPTION_PROJECT_LEAD instead of SAP_CBC_CONSUMPTION_PROGRAM_LEAD(Program Manager), otherwise you might not be able to see the conflict tab later. You can refer to the KBA 3661733 - Conflicts tab is raising authorization error

entry.title: SAP CPI - IBMMQ adapter setup MQRC_JSSE_ERROR.
entry.content:
I need help understanding why IBM MQ adapter in CPI does not connect to MQ server due to SSL/TLS problems with MQRC_JSSE_ERROR.

Using WebSphere MQ 9.3.0.5 on Windows.

Steps to setup:
1. Create self-signed cert on MQ Server, 

runmqakm -keydb -create -db srt04684.kdb -pw <secret> -type cms -stash

runmqakm -cert -create -db srt04684.kdb  -pw <secret> -label ibmwebspheremqqm1010t -dn "CN=srt04684,C=SE"  -size 2048  -x509version 3 -expire 730 -sig_alg SHA256WithRSA

runmqakm -cert -extract -db srt04684.kdb -pw <secret> -label ibmwebspheremqqm1010t -target srt04684.arm -format ascii

2. Config QMGR, including copying certificate files to /ssl directory and updating QMGR SSL key repository (excluding .kbd), setting the password and also setting the certificate label to "ibmwebspheremqqm1010t"

3. Create SVRCONN channel SAPISCLIENT.CH, set CipherSpec to "TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256" (have tried multiple others). No SSL Authentication.

4. Restart QMGR

5.Config cloud connector, with virtual name matching the servername "srt04684", port 1414. Verified connectivity

entry.title: Re: Employee Filtering in “Manage Teams and Responsibilit...
entry.content:
Good day @MuratTnrkt 

Thank you for your question.

Have a lok at these references for more details.

Resource Scheduling, Manage Teams and Responsibilities, Implementing Data Replication from Employee

Central, Integration with Business Partner

Based on your description, it seems there is a missing linkage between the workforce data and the data you have maintained in your Business partner.

In summary, the app does not display all Business Partners but only your active workforce persons who meet some predefined conditions such as:

  • Having an active employment record in the Workforce Person master.
  • Are linked to a valid Business Partner (Employee Role _ BUP003).
  • Have a valid organisational assignment within the current date range.
  • Are integrated through the Workforce Integration (SAP_COM_0107) scenario or maintained through Manage Workforce.

To Identify who appears and why they do,

Ensure you compare the data in Manage Workforce against Maintain Business Partner

Ensure each BP is linked to a workforce Person ID, and confirm that the employment is active and valid for today’s date.

You also have the possibility if needed, to use the CDS views I_WorkforcePerson and I_BusinessPartnerWorkforceLink to create a reconciliation query.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Fiori Elements list report controller extension typescript : editFlow().getView() does not work
entry.content:
@SumitKundu: when I paste the above file into a new SAPUI5 app, then the first TypeScript error I get is: "Type 'ControllerExtension' is not generic.". Indeed, the type does not allow generics like "ControllerExtension<ExtensionAPI>". And this is true: the class does not have generics, as you can see in the documentation (https://ui5.sap.com/#/api/sap.ui.core.mvc.ControllerExtension) and also in the UI5 type definitions. When I remove the <ExtensionAPI> part, then this.getView() works fine. 

I do see discussions like https://github.com/SAP/open-ux-tools/issues/841#issuecomment-1354440504 by Fiori Elements colleagues that intend to override our type and extend it with generics. I also see such an override being added in a template in https://github.com/SAP/open-ux-tools/pull/858/files and indeed, with this hack, the this.getView() is no longer accepted.

I guess something like this is in place in your app. I'd suggest that the Fiori Elements colleagues have a look in this case.

entry.title: eDocument SII – Canceled invoice before submission does not generate “accepted” status
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am working with the eDocument process for SII in Spain and I have encountered the following situation:

  • I create a customer invoice.

  • Before submitting it to the SII, I cancel that same invoice.

  • Afterwards, I perform the SII submission.

The result is that an eDocument is generated with status “canceled”, but no eDocument is created for the original invoice with status “accepted”.

My questions are:

  1. Why does the system not generate an eDocument with status “accepted” for the original invoice, even though it was later canceled?

  2. Is this the standard SAP behavior (only creating the cancellation eDocument if the invoice was never transmitted)?

  3. Is there any configuration or SAP Note that allows the system to also generate the “accepted” eDocument in these cases?

  4. Is it possible to generate the XML file for both the original invoice and the canceled invoice, even if the original one was never sent to the SII?

I would really appreciate any guidance or experiences you can share.

Thank you very much,

Jessica Aguil

entry.title: Re: Frontend Strategies for SAP Sales Cloud V2: An Architect’s Perspective on Modern UI Extensions
entry.content:
Hello @StKollos ,

Thank you very much for your thoughtful comment and for sharing your experiences—much appreciated!

I wanted to share my perspective, though I am not a decision-maker regarding the design choices in SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2. From what I have observed, development teams often have a certain level of freedom when working on extensions. This can be influenced by factors such as skill sets, familiarity with tools like Fiori Elements, SAP Build, or web components, and sometimes the business not being fully convinced about following the standard Fiori approach.

This flexibility can occasionally lead to different directions and inconsistencies in the UI, but it can also foster unique innovations that might not emerge within a strictly standardized framework.

I completely agree with your point about the V2 web components https://github.com/SAP/fundamental-ngx—they do seem like a valuable option to simplify development and improve consistency. Making such a UI library officially available would likely benefit many teams and ensure a more uniform, user-friendly experience.

I’d love to hear the perspectives of other UX architects or experts on this matter, as it’s always valuable to learn from diverse experiences

Thanks again for sharing your insights—they add a lot of value to this discussion!

 

Regards,

Showkath

entry.title: Embedded launch activities for SAP SuccessFactors HCM: Your Guide to the Demo Environment
entry.content:
This blog post provides demo scripts for SAP SuccessFactors HCM as part of our embedded launch activities offering. It complements your guided enablement learning by allowing you to practice within a pre-configured demo environment after reviewing the best practices in your Learning Journey. The learning journeys provide focussed guidance on these project roles. - Project Manager, IT Lead, and Business User. The demo scripts offer step-by-step, guidance for a hands-on experience for anyone who wants to understand and become familiar with the leading practices.

For information on your eligibility and how to request access to the demo environment, please refer to the details here.

To begin, use the Demo Navigation Guide to familiarize yourself with the basic functions of the embedded launch activities demo environment (login, home page, org chart, etc.). This is the recommended first step for all beginners.

Demo Scripts Overview

The demo scripts are designed to walk you through the above modules as a user. Each script focuses on the key functionalities of the respective module and provides a step-by-step guide on how different personas interact with the system.

Following demo scripts are available for you:

    1. Manage Workforce 1 (Employee Central)
    2. Manage Workforce 2 (Employee Central)
    3. Manage Workforce 3 (Employee Central)
    4. Recruit to Onboard (Recruiting and Onboarding)
    5. Identify and Grow (Performance and Goals Management, Career Development and Succession)
    6. Educate and Develop (Learning , Career Development  and  Succession)
    7. Reward to Retain (Compensation & Benefits)
    8. Time Off  (Time & Attendance)
    9. Time Sheets (Time & Attendance)
    10. Time Tracking (Time & Attendance)

A Quick Note on the Demo Environment usage:

The demo environment is designed to showcase the specific SAP best practices in our demo scripts. For custom scenarios or advanced testing, we recommend working with your implementation partner in your licensed development environment.

Additionally, your project team should use the demo environment to become familiar with SuccessFactors, our leading practices, and various user roles. We do not recommend the demo environment for building business-specific solutions, end user testing, or as a training platform.SAP embedded launch activities demo environment is the perfect way to familiarize your team with the SuccessFactors user experience and build excitement for your project.

If you have any questions, leave a comment below or email our team at SAP_Embedded_Launch_Activities_SF@sap.com

Happy Learning!

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to include values from multiple models...
entry.content:
Hi @tsuuuu, based on your requirement to display values from multiple models in a single input control, here's a solution using public dimensions:

  1. Create a public dimension for Company Code that contains all the company code values used across both Model1 and Model2 (including TEST and TEST2).

  2. Ensure both models are mapped to this same public dimension for the Company Code field. This is crucial for the solution to work properly.

  3. Create an input control in your story using either Model1 or Model2 as the source model (it doesn't matter which one you choose).

  4. Enable "Show Unbooked Values" (or "Unbooked Members" depending on your SAC version) in the input control settings. By default, the input control only displays dimension values that have transaction records in the selected model. Enabling this setting will display all values from the public dimension, regardless of whether they have data in the specific model.

Result: Your single input control will now show all company codes (TEST, TEST2, and any others) from the public dimension, effectively displaying values from both models.

Important Note: When users make selections in this input control, it will filter both models in your chart since they share the same public dimension. This works seamlessly with the linked dimensions feature you've already set up in your story.

This approach leverages SAP Analytics Cloud's dimensional architecture to achieve exactly what you're looking for - one input control controlling multiple models through a shared dimension.

Let me know if you need any clarification or if there are additional aspects to your use case!

entry.title: Re: F150 send by email and spool
entry.content:
The answer might depend on the printing technology you are using: with Adobe PDF, setting the getpdf flag when opening the job will prevent the generation of the spool. I am not sure if the same holds true for Smartforms and Sapscript but the solution could well be the same.

Set up the whole process to print, forget about email for a second: when the normal print is done, locate the spool and convert it to pdf. At this point, you are allowed to remember that you wanted to send it by email 🙂

REPORT zabo_test_print_and_pdf.

DATA gs_docparams    TYPE sfpdocparams.
DATA gs_formoutput   TYPE fpformoutput.
DATA gs_outputparams TYPE sfpoutputparams.
DATA gs_result       TYPE sfpjoboutput.
DATA gt_pdf          TYPE TABLE OF tline.
DATA gv_fm_name      TYPE rs38l_fnam.
* We deliberately use a standard form to avoid interactions
DATA gv_formname     TYPE fpname VALUE 'FP_TEST_00'.
DATA gv_pdf          TYPE xstring.
DATA gv_size         TYPE i.
DATA gv_spool_id     TYPE rspoid.

"------------------------------------------------------------
" 1. Open ADS job
"------------------------------------------------------------
gs_outputparams-dest     = 'LP01'.        " printer (must exist in SPAD)
gs_outputparams-reqnew   = abap_true.     " new spool request
gs_outputparams-reqimm   = space.
gs_outputparams-reqdel   = space.
gs_outputparams-nodialog = abap_true.     " no print dialog
* in the standard, PDF generation and Spool are mutually exclusive!
gs_outputparams-getpdf   = abap_false.

CALL FUNCTION 'FP_JOB_OPEN'
  CHANGING   ie_outputparams = gs_outputparams
  EXCEPTIONS cancel          = 1
             usage_error     = 2
             system_error    = 3
             internal_error  = 4
             OTHERS          = 5.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE e398(00) WITH 'FP_JOB_OPEN failed' sy-subrc.
  LEAVE PROGRAM.
ENDIF.

"------------------------------------------------------------
" 2. Determine generated function module name for the form
"------------------------------------------------------------
CALL FUNCTION 'FP_FUNCTION_MODULE_NAME'
  EXPORTING  i_name     = gv_formname
  IMPORTING  e_funcname = gv_fm_name
  EXCEPTIONS OTHERS     = 1.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE e398(00) WITH 'FP_FUNCTION_MODULE_NAME failed' sy-subrc.
  LEAVE PROGRAM.
ENDIF.

"------------------------------------------------------------
" 3. Call generated form FM
"------------------------------------------------------------
DATA itf TYPE tsftext.
FIELD-SYMBOLS <fs_itf> TYPE tline.

APPEND INITIAL LINE TO itf ASSIGNING <fs_itf>.
<fs_itf>-tdline = 'hello'.

CALL FUNCTION gv_fm_name
  EXPORTING  /1bcdwb/docparams  = gs_docparams
             textlines          = itf "Whatever the form requires as arguments...
  IMPORTING  /1bcdwb/formoutput = gs_formoutput
  EXCEPTIONS usage_error        = 1
             system_error       = 2
             internal_error     = 3
             OTHERS             = 4.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE e398(00) WITH 'Form call failed' sy-subrc.
ENDIF.

"------------------------------------------------------------
" 4. Close ADS job (creates spool)
"------------------------------------------------------------
CALL FUNCTION 'FP_JOB_CLOSE'
  IMPORTING  e_result       = gs_result
  EXCEPTIONS usage_error    = 1
             system_error   = 2
             internal_error = 3
             OTHERS         = 4.

BREAK-POINT.
" check gs_formoutput-pdf: should be empty when getpdf = space

IF sy-subrc = 0 AND gs_result-spoolids[] IS NOT INITIAL.
  WRITE / 'Spool request created'.
ELSE.
  WRITE / 'No spool request created!'.
ENDIF.

"------------------------------------------------------------
" 5. Generate with spool only (getpdf = space)
"------------------------------------------------------------
READ TABLE gs_result-spoolids INDEX 1 INTO gv_spool_id.
CHECK sy-subrc = 0.

" 6. Convert spool to PDF
CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERT_ABAPSPOOLJOB_2_PDF'
  EXPORTING  src_spoolid            = gv_spool_id
             no_dialog              = 'X'
  IMPORTING  pdf_bytecount          = gv_size
  TABLES     pdf                    = gt_pdf
  EXCEPTIONS err_no_abap_spooljob   = 1
             err_no_spooljob        = 2
             err_no_permission      = 3
             err_conv_not_possible  = 4
             err_bad_destdevice     = 5
             user_cancelled         = 6
             err_spoolid_not_exists = 7
             OTHERS                 = 8.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
  " Convert table to xstring
  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING'
    EXPORTING  input_length = gv_size
    IMPORTING  buffer       = gv_pdf
    TABLES     binary_tab   = gt_pdf
    EXCEPTIONS failed       = 1
               OTHERS       = 2.
ENDIF.

BREAK-POINT.
" check gv_pdf...

entry.title: Routing APL tasks to an Elastic Compute Node
entry.content:
In this blog you will see how APL (Automated Predictive Library) addresses compute-intensive peak workloads by leveraging ECNs (Elastic Compute Nodes). The following example will walk you through the steps required to route an APL task to an ECN running on HANA Cloud.

In our case the ECN is named ecn1. It has been provisioned via HANA Cloud Central. For information on ECN provisioning see https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/harnessing-dynamic-elasticity-elastic-compute-node-for-smarter-scaling-in/ba-p/14016836

To allow the execution of APL functions by the ECN, we configure as admin user a workload class using this line of SQL:

create WORKLOAD CLASS WC4 SET 'ROUTING LOCATION HINT' = 'ecn1';

This is just one way among many to create a workload class in HANA Cloud.

 

Working with the APL Python interface

As admin user ...

from hana_ml import dataframe as hd
conn = hd.ConnectionContext(
    address = 'Host_String', port = 443, 
    user = 'DBADMIN', password = 'Password_String', 
    encrypt = 'true', sslValidateCertificate = 'false' )
conn.connection.isconnected()

... it is possible to check if the ECN is active with this query:

sql_cmd =  'select volume_id, host, port, service_name FROM M_VOLUMES order by 1'
hd.DataFrame(conn, sql_cmd).collect()

 

 

Before calling the APL function, we clear the SQL cache:

import pandas as pd
from hdbcli import dbapi
def clear_sql_cache():
    with conn.connection.cursor() as cur:
        cur.execute("ALTER SYSTEM CLEAR SQL PLAN CACHE")
clear_sql_cache()

Let’s jump now to a second notebook where we run, as APL user this time, a forecasting task:

from hana_ml import dataframe as hd
conn = hd.ConnectionContext(
    address = 'Host_String', port = 443, 
    user = 'USER_APL', password = 'Password_String', 
    encrypt = 'true', sslValidateCertificate = 'false' )
conn.connection.isconnected()

We define a dataframe for the input series ...

series_in = conn.table('OZONE_RATE_LA', schema='APL_SAMPLES')

... and run the forecast after specyfying the workload class WC4 for the routing to happen:

from hana_ml.algorithms.apl.time_series import AutoTimeSeries
apl_model = AutoTimeSeries(time_column_name= 'Date', target= 'OzoneRateLA', horizon= 12)
apl_model.set_scale_out(workload_class="WC4") 
## apl_model.set_scale_out(route_to=1025)  # Alternative option
series_out = apl_model.fit_predict(data = series_in, build_report=True)

Last, we go back to our first notebook, and verify that the APL functions ran indeed on the ECN:

sql_cmd =  """ 
select HOST, VOLUME_ID, APPLICATION_NAME, STATEMENT_STRING, LAST_EXECUTION_TIMESTAMP
from M_SQL_PLAN_CACHE 
where USER_NAME= 'USER_APL' and LAST_EXECUTION_TIMESTAMP is not null and STATEMENT_STRING LIKE 'CALL %'
order by LAST_EXECUTION_TIMESTAMP
"""
hd.DataFrame(conn, sql_cmd).collect()

 

 

 

Working with the APL SQL interface

As APL user, to ensure that the forecast is executed by the ECN, we put the APL script inside a stored procedure, say MDA_APL_FORECAST, and then we call that procedure using a hint as follows:

call MDA_APL_FORECAST with HINT(WORKLOAD_CLASS(WC4));

As admin user, we check that the routing worked with the code below:

select HOST, VOLUME_ID, APPLICATION_NAME, STATEMENT_STRING, LAST_EXECUTION_TIMESTAMP
from M_SQL_PLAN_CACHE 
where USER_NAME= 'USER_APL' and LAST_EXECUTION_TIMESTAMP is not null 
order by LAST_EXECUTION_TIMESTAMP;

 

Here is the sample code we used to create the stored procedure:

create type FORECAST_OUT_T as table (
 "Date" 	DATE,
 "OzoneRateLA" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Trend" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Cycles" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_lowerlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_upperlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1ExtraPreds" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Fluctuations" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Residues" DOUBLE
);
create table FORECAST_OUT like FORECAST_OUT_T;

create table OP_LOG like "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_LOG";
create table SUMMARY like "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.SUMMARY";
create table DEBRIEF_METRIC like "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_METRIC_OID";
create table DEBRIEF_PROPERTY like "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_PROPERTY_OID";

create procedure "MDA_APL_FORECAST" 
as BEGIN
    declare out_forecast FORECAST_OUT_T;
    declare header "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.FUNCTION_HEADER";
    declare config "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_CONFIG_DETAILED";
	declare var_desc "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_DESC_OID";   
    declare var_role "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_ROLES_WITH_COMPOSITES_OID";    
    declare apl_log   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_LOG";      
    declare apl_sum   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.SUMMARY";   
    declare apl_indic   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.INDICATORS";   	
    declare apl_metr "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_METRIC_OID";
    declare apl_prop "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_PROPERTY_OID";      

    :header.insert(('Oid', 'Monthly Ozone Rate'));

    :config.insert(('APL/Horizon', '12',null));
    :config.insert(('APL/TimePointColumnName', 'Date',null));
    :config.insert(('APL/LastTrainingTimePoint', '1971-12-28 00:00:00',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ForcePositiveForecast', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/DecomposeInfluencers', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ApplyExtraMode', 'First Forecast with Stable Components and Residues and Error Bars',null));
	
    :var_role.insert(('Date', 'input', null, null, null));
    :var_role.insert(('OzoneRateLA', 'target', null, null, null));

    dataset  = select * from APL_SAMPLES.OZONE_RATE_LA order by "Date" asc;  
	
    "_SYS_AFL"."APL_FORECAST__OVERLOAD_5_6" (
	:header, :config, :var_desc, :var_role, :dataset, 
	out_forecast, apl_log, apl_sum, apl_indic, apl_metr, apl_prop );

	insert into  FORECAST_OUT      select * from :out_forecast;
	insert into  OP_LOG    	       select * from :apl_log;
	insert into  SUMMARY   	       select * from :apl_sum;
	insert into  DEBRIEF_METRIC    select * from :apl_metr;
	insert into  DEBRIEF_PROPERTY  select * from :apl_prop;
END;

Note that for this basic sample we stored the full debrief tables. However, if your predictive use case involves a segmented APL model with many segments, it is preferable to extract only the information needed by the end-users, so that the amount of output data is reduced. Here is an example on how to obtain a couple of accuracy indicators by segment:

    insert into  "USER_APL"."MDA_FORECAST_ACCURACY" 
    select "Oid" as "Segment", "MAE", "MAPE"
    from "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::TimeSeries_Performance" 
    (:apl_prop, :apl_metr)
    where "Partition" = 'Validation';

 

To know more about APL

entry.title: IAS-IPS (SAP Security)
entry.content:
IAS & IPS

 

 

Content :

  1. SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)
  2. SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)
  3. Real World Scenario

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)

IAS is SAP’s cloud-based authentication service.

Its core job is to make sure “the right user logs in securely to the right SAP application.”

Think of IAS as the gatekeeper.

 

What IAS Does

  1. Authenticates Users (Login / Sign-in)

IAS verifies user identity when they try to log in to:

  • SAP BTP
  • SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Any custom application connected to IAS

It checks:

  • Username + Password
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (OTP, SMS, Email, Authenticator App)
  • Certificates
  • Biometrics (via device IdP)

 

  1. Single Sign-On (SSO)

IAS supports:

  • SAML 2.0
  • OAuth 2.0
  • OpenID Connect (OIDC)

So your users log in once and access all SAP apps without logging in again.

 

  1. Acts as an Identity Provider (IdP)
  • IAS can serve as

Primary IdP

  • IAS handles authentication directly

Proxy IdP

  • IAS redirects authentication to:
  1. Microsoft Azure AD
  2. ADFS
  3. Okta
  4. Ping Identity
  5. Any SAML-based IdP

IAS becomes the bridge between SAP systems and corporate identity providers.

 

  1. Conditional Authentication Policies

IAS can decide:

  • Who can log in
  • From where
  • Under what conditions

Examples:

  • Allow MFA only when user logs in from outside office
  • Block login from certain countries
  • Force password reset for risky accounts
  • Apply SSO only for trusted devices

 

  1. User Store (Identity Directory)

IAS stores user accounts, including:

  • Username
  • Email
  • First Name / Last Name
  • Groups
  • Password (if local authentication)

Note : BUT IAS does NOT create users automatically — IPS usually does provisioning.

 

  1. Authorization Pre-Processing (via Groups → Mappings)

IAS can assign groups, and these groups can be mapped in target apps (like SAP BTP) to give role collections.

  • IAS Group = “FinanceUsers”

→ Mapped to

  • BTP Role Collection = “Finance App Access”

But IAS itself does NOT assign app roles.

Note : IAS group can only be mapped to BTP role collections, not to PFCG Role etc.

 

  1. Branding & Custom Login Pages

IAS allows full customization of login screens:

  • Company logo
  • Color theme
  • Background
  • Messages
  • Terms & conditions

 

  1. Security Enforcement

IAS applies:

  • Password policies
  • MFA rules
  • Account lockout rules
  • Device trust
  • Risk-based authentication

 

What IAS Does NOT Do

  • IAS does NOT create users(IPS or external IdP does)
  • IAS group does NOT assign roles in S/4, SAC, Ariba, etc.
  • IAS does NOT do provisioning(IPS does)
  • IAS does NOT perform GRC / SoD checks(IAG does)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)

IPS is SAP’s central user provisioning and synchronization service.

It moves users from one system to another, ensuring that user accounts, attributes, and group/role assignments stay consistent across:

  • SAP BTP
  • IAS (Identity Authentication Service)
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Azure AD, Okta, Ping, etc.

Think of IPS as the “delivery service” for user accounts.

 

What IPS Does

  1. Creates Users in Target Systems

IPS automatically provisions users into multiple systems.

Example:
SuccessFactors → IPS → IAS → BTP → S/4HANA

IPS can create user accounts in:

  • IAS
  • SAP BTP
  • S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP Concur
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (via SCIM)

 

  1. Updates User Attributes

If an employee changes department, email, manager, etc., IPS updates the data in all connected systems.

Example:
SuccessFactors updates → IPS sync → IAS/BTP/S4/Ariba update

 

  1. Deletes / Deactivates Users

When an employee leaves the company, IPS can mark them inactive or delete their user account.

 

  1. Maps and Transforms Attributes

IPS allows:

  • Attribute mapping
  • Attribute transformation
  • Conditional provisioning

Example:
IF user.department = "Finance" → assign group “FIN_USERS”

 

  1. Assigns Groups / Roles (but not everywhere)

IPS can assign:

  • IAS Groups
  • BTP Role Collections
  • S/4HANA Business Roles
  • SAP Ariba groups
  • SAC roles (via SCIM)

But only where system supports it.

 

  1. Connects to Many Identity Sources

IPS can read users from:

  • Azure AD
  • SuccessFactors
  • IAS
  • LDAP
  • Okta
  • On-premise systems (via Cloud Connector)

What IPS does NOT do

  • IPS does NOT Authenticate Users (IAS does)

 

Real World Scenario

 

 



Company:

A global manufacturing company using:

  • SAP SuccessFactors (HR system of record)
  • SAP BTP (custom apps, Integration Suite)
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud (ERP)
  • SAP Ariba (Procurement)
  • SAP IAS (Authentication)
  • SAP IPS (Provisioning)
  • SAP IAG (Access Governance)

Scenario 1: A New Employee Joins the Company

Step 1 — Employee is Hired in SuccessFactors

HR creates a new employee: Rohan Sharma with below details

  • Department: Finance
  • Location: India
  • Manager: Priya Singh
  • Job: Accounts Payable Analyst

SuccessFactors stores all HR attributes.

Step 2 — IPS Reads Rohan’s Data from SuccessFactors

IPS acts as the "provisioning engine."

Flow: SuccessFactors → IPS → IAS

IPS automatically:

  • Reads new user
  • Maps attributes
  • Creates user in IAS
  • Assigns IAS group “Finance_Employees”
  • Pushes email, username, and department

Step 3 — IAS Creates User Entry + Prepares Authentication

IAS now has user:

  • Username: rohan.sharma
  • Email: rohan.sharma@company.com
  • Group: Finance_Employees
  • Status: Active

IAS does NOT assign roles.

IAS only sets up login policies:

  • MFA required
  • Corporate SSO allowed
  • Conditional rule: India region → allow password login

Step 4 — IAG Triggers Access Request Workflow

Rohan needs access to:

  • SAP BTP Finance App
  • S/4HANA Finance Business Roles
  • Ariba Buyer Role

In large companies, users cannot get access automatically,they must request access via IAG.

Flow:

  1. Rohan goes to IAG Access Request Portal
  2. Selects: "Finance Analyst Access Package"
  3. Request goes to Manager (Priya Singh)
  4. IAG performs SoD checks  No conflicting roles  No risk
  5. Manager approves

Step 5 — IAG Sends Provisioning Action to IPS

After approval:

IAG → IPS → Target Systems

IPS now provisions the approved roles

  • In SAP BTP: Assigns BTP Role Collection:

Finance_Analyst_RoleCollection

 

  • In S/4HANA Cloud: Assigns Business Roles:

AP_STANDARD

FIN_POSTING

FIN_DISPLAY

 

  • In SAP Ariba: Assigns Ariba group:

Buyer_Professional

 

Step 6 — Rohan Logs In to SAP Systems

Rohan logs in to:

SAP BTP App

  • IAS checks login
  • IAS → BTP trusts IAS
  • BTP picks up role collection assigned via IPS

S/4HANA Cloud

  • Login route:
  • Browser → IAS → S/4
  • S/4 checks Business Role assignments provisioned via IPS

Ariba

  • IAS federates login → Ariba validates user groups

Step 7 — Rohan Changes Department (Employee Movement)

After 1 year, Rohan moves from Finance to Supply Chain.

HR updates this in SuccessFactors.

  • IPS reads update
  • IPS updates IAS + BTP + S/4HANA + Ariba
  • IAG dynamically checks if old roles must be removed.
  • Roles get de-provisioned: Finance roles removed & New Supply Chain roles added

Step 8 — Employee Exit

When Rohan leaves company:

  • HR marks employee as terminated in SuccessFactors
  • IPS deactivates him in IAS
  • IPS removes roles in BTP, S/4, Ariba
  • IAS blocks login

User access fully revoked

entry.title: Re: Monetary award without any guidelines - Compensation
entry.content:
Implementing a monetary award system such as a SPOT award without any guidelines can be risky, as the lack of structure may lead to inconsistency, potential biases, and perceptions of unfairness. However, if you still wish to proceed, here are some considerations to ensure it works as effectively as possible:

  1. Clear Objectives: Define what behaviors or achievements the SPOT award is intended to recognize, even if they are broad. This helps employees understand the purpose of the awards.

  2. Transparency: Communicate openly about the existence of the award and its purpose. This can help manage expectations and reduce misunderstandings.

  3. Managerial Discretion: Empower managers to use their discretion to nominate employees for the award based on outstanding contributions. However, encourage them to document reasons for their choices to maintain some level of accountability.

  4. Simple Process: Keep the nomination and approval process as simple as possible. This can encourage frequent use of the award system without overburdening employees or managers.

  5. Feedback and Adjustment: Regularly gather feedback from employees and managers about the award's impact and adjust the approach as necessary. This can help ensure the awards remain relevant and appreciated.

  6. Recognize and Celebrate: Publicly acknowledge award recipients to reinforce positive behavior and motivate others.

  7. Trial Period: Consider implementing the award system on a trial basis, even without guidelines, to assess its effectiveness and make improvements.

While it's feasible to start without set guidelines, it's generally advisable to develop some framework over time to ensure the SPOT award system is fair, motivating, and aligned with organizational goals.

entry.title: Re: Procurement of Services in SAP Ariba
entry.content:
Taxes in Planned Service PO (Parent-Child Service Hierarchy)

We can have Tax passed in parent line of a Service PO auto-flipped when creating an Invoice as a supplier on SAP Business Network. This helps reducing manual tax error on supplier side. For this to work, we need the following pre-requisites:

1. Planned Service PO is created with tax details even for child service line as seen is screen below. Kindly ensure that Parameter Application.Procure.DefaultAllChildLinesAsServiceItems is set to default value 'No' for this to work well.
2. Default Transaction Rule for Invoice 'Copy tax from purchase order to standard invoice' is enabled.
3. Business Network Feature CSC-16389 is enabled (with the help of SAP Ariba Support). This feature allows tax details to flip from service PO parent line to child lines on Network side.

Service PR & PO with Tax Details

The default functionality on Network is that tax can only be automatically flipped during Invoice creation if already present in child line of a service PO. For details, refer
Why does the tax passed in parent line of service purchase order (PO) not auto flip when creating an invoice?

Invoice with Tax Details

entry.title: Re: Script Gui - How to get the contents of a GuiGridView...
entry.content:
To retrieve the contents of a row in a GuiGridView, you typically need to interact with the GUI scripting capabilities of the environment you're working in. If you are working with SAP GUI scripting via SAP GUI for Windows, here's a basic approach using VBScript. This is a common scripting language used for automating tasks within the SAP environment.

Here's a general way to access row data in a GuiGridView using VBScript within the context of SAP GUI scripting:

 
If Not IsObject(application) Then
    Set SapGuiAuto = GetObject("SAPGUI")
    Set application = SapGuiAuto.GetScriptingEngine
End If
If Not IsObject(connection) Then
    Set connection = application.Children(0)
End If
If Not IsObject(session) Then
    Set session = connection.Children(0)
End If

' Replace "wnd[0]/usr/cntlGRIDVIEW/shellcont/shell" with the actual ID of your GuiGridView
If Not IsObject(gridView) Then
    Set gridView = session.FindById("wnd[0]/usr/cntlGRIDVIEW/shellcont/shell")
End If

' Specify the row number you want to retrieve. Row numbers typically start at 0.
rowIndex = 0

' Get the number of columns in the grid view
columnCount = gridView.ColumnCount

' Create an array to store row contents
Dim rowData()
ReDim rowData(columnCount - 1)

' Retrieve the contents of each cell in the specified row
For i = 0 To columnCount - 1
    rowData(i) = gridView.GetCellValue(rowIndex, i)
Next

' Display the contents of the row
For i = 0 To UBound(rowData)
    WScript.Echo "Column " & i & ": " & rowData(i)
Next

Steps Explained:

  1. Connect to SAP GUI: This part of the script establishes a connection to an existing SAP session.

  2. Access the GuiGridView: You need to find the grid view by its ID. The ID will be unique to your SAP screen and setup. Adjust the string in FindById to match the path to your grid view component.

  3. Retrieve Row Contents: Specify the row index you are interested in. The script iterates through each cell in that row and retrieves the content using GetCellValue.

  4. Output the Data: The script then outputs the content of each cell.

Make sure to customize the script according to your SAP GUI environment, specifically the IDs and indices which depend on the application’s layout and implementation. This solution assumes that SAP GUI scripting is enabled in your environment. Ensure you have the necessary permissions and that scripting is activated on the SAP server and client.

entry.title: Re: Invoicing in SAP Ariba
entry.content:
Taxes in Planned Service PO (Parent-Child Service Hierarchy)

We can have Tax passed in parent line of a Service PO auto-flipped when creating an Invoice as a supplier on SAP Business Network. This helps reducing manual tax error on supplier side. For this to work, we need the following pre-requisites:

1. Planned Service PO is created with tax details even for child service line as seen is screen below. Kindly ensure that Parameter Application.Procure.DefaultAllChildLinesAsServiceItems is set to default value 'No' for this to work well.
2. Default Transaction Rule for Invoice 'Copy tax from purchase order to standard invoice' is enabled.
3. Business Network Feature CSC-16389 is enabled (with the help of SAP Ariba Support). This feature allows tax details to flip from service PO parent line to child lines on Network side.

Service PR & PO with Tax Details

The default functionality on Network is that tax can only be automatically flipped during Invoice creation if already present in child line of a service PO. For details, refer Why does the tax passed in parent line of service purchase order (PO) not auto flip when creating an...

Invoice with Tax Details

entry.title: MDI vs. CPI: Master Data Decisions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud to SAP Field Service Management
entry.content:
To power a consistent service operation in SAP Field Service Management (FSM), your master data from S/4HANA Public Cloud must flow seamlessly. This blog series cuts straight to the core question: How do you choose the right data replication strategy? I will detail the differences between replication via SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) and SAP Cloud Integration (CPI).

Additionally, will walk through the configurations required in S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Master Data Integration (MDI), detail the FSM-side configuration using the MDI Connector, and show how to monitor replication and consume MDI APIs for read access. Practical tips and configuration examples will help you evaluate trade-offs and implement a reliable replication landscape.

Feature Face-Off between MDI & CPI approaches:

Choosing the right approach for master data integration between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP Field Service Management (FSM) boils down to prioritizing flexibility vs. governance. SAP offers two primary technical solutions: SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) and SAP Master Data Integration (MDI). While CPI uses dedicated integration flows for replication, MDI uses a centralized, hub-and-spoke approach based on the SAP One Domain Model, eliminating the need for complex point-to-point connections, especially in landscapes involving multiple applications like SAP SuccessFactors, Ariba, or Fieldglass. MDI also provides robust, built-in features for data filtering and is commercially free for integration between SAP-branded cloud solutions.

The core difference between the solutions lies in flexibility versus standardization, which impacts how you manage complex landscapes and data governance.

Customization and Data Scope

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CPI): Offers full capability to modify field and value mappings via iFlows, providing maximum control for complex or unique transformation needs.
  • SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): Currently, MDI does not offer customization capabilities for field or value mappings. However, MDI is superior for data governance, allowing convenient filtering of replicated objects and field subsets via the SAP Business Data Orchestration app.

Multi-Company & Complex Landscapes

  • Multi-Company Support: Both solutions can handle replicating data from a single S/4HANA client to multiple companies in SAP FSM. CPI is noted as being slightly more flexible in this regard.
  • Complex Application Landscapes: MDI's primary strength is the hub-and-spoke approach. It is specifically designed for complex environments that include applications beyond FSM, such as SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and SAP Fieldglass. This centralized approach and the common One Domain Model eliminate the need to set up multiple, brittle point-to-point integrations.

Operational Stability and Monitoring

Handling large data volumes and ensuring continuous data flow are critical. MDI provides dedicated tooling within FSM for better visibility and retry capabilities.

Advanced Asynchronous Processing

The MDI Connector for FSM is designed to ensure that incoming master data is replicated at a sustainable rate. This prevents the data load from negatively impacting the performance of transactional processing within SAP Field Service Management. While CPI also implements throttling measures, exceptionally large initial loads using CPI may still affect the overall perceived performance in FSM.

Object-Based Logging and Error Handling

  • MDI: Replication monitoring is handled directly within FSM via the MDI Connector Replication Report. In case an object fails replication (despite automatic retries), the MDI Connector Errors page in FSM lists the failures and provides the capability to manually retry the replication once the inconsistency is resolved.
  • CPI: Monitoring is managed through the SAP Cloud Integration Monitor in the SAP BTP cockpit. While Message Processing Logs help in tracing the flow, complex transformations within the iFlows may require careful optimization and monitoring.

 

SAP Cloud Integration is the optimal choice for organizations requiring maximum customization and control over their data mappings or those with minimal application landscapes. Conversely, SAP Master Data Integration is the strategic choice for future proofing and simplifying complex landscapes. It promotes standardization, offers superior tools for data governance, and provides better operational stability during bulk processing.

Below are the available standard integration content for integrating Master data from S/4HANA Cloud Public to SAP FSM:

  • Master Data Integration with MDI Connector – Integration is done using SAP FSM MDI Connector which directly connects to MDI to pull the data using change events.
  • Integration of Service in SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Field Service Management – Integration is done using standard Cloud Integration package, this covers both master and transactional data.
  • Additionally, with MDI approach there is another standard Cloud Integration package “SAP Master Data Integration with SAP Field Service Management” which bypasses the FSM MDI connector setup to replicate solely the Business Partners & its relationship data into FSM. But this approach is not recommended anymore as we now have FSM MDI Connector which connects directly to SAP MDI to integrate business partner/relationships and other business objects. This integration package will be deprecated in near future.

 

Object coverage that you can replicate:

Object Type

SAP Cloud Integration

SAP MDI

Business Partners (with Relationships)

Yes

Yes

Contacts

Yes

Yes

Products

Yes

Yes

Product Groups

Yes

Yes

Product Price

Yes

No

Product Stock

Yes

No

Equipment/Functional locations

Supported through Asset Central Foundation

Yes

Workforce Person

No

Yes

Note:

  • Workforce Data: The Workforce Person object is only supported via SAP Master Data Integration.
  • Asset Data: Replication of Equipment/Functional Location via CPI relies on Asset Central Foundation, which has limited field support and currently restricts the transfer to delta loads only (no initial load).
  • Field Mapping: While most field sets are similar, MDI uses the SAP One Data Model, which may result in slight differences from the native S/4HANA data model. In CPI approach, you can customize the mapping using pre and post extensions.

Further, in the below follow blog, I will detail you with the step-by-step configurations required in S/4HANA Cloud, SAP MDI (BTP), & SAP FSM MDI Connector. Also, will share details on how to monitor data replication when using MDI Connector approach and necessary MDI APIs.

 

Ready to build it? The next blog will show you how. Click the link below for a full walkthrough covering all essential configurations in S/4HANA Cloud, SAP MDI, and the FSM MDI Connector, complete with monitoring tips and MDI API usage.

<blog 2 link>
